title: Expedia couldn't find my booking so I ended up paying twice
text:

Fri, Oct 9, 2015, 11:41 BST - UK Markets close in 4 hrs 49 mins Expedia couldn't find my booking so I ended up paying twice By Amelia Murray | Telegraph – 27 minutes ago -0.05 
This consumer entered her email address wrongly - a mistake which cost £118 
When booking a flight or buying anything online, it's your responsibility to enter your details correctly. 
But inevitably mistakes are made - and it's what happens then that highlights the radically different approaches taken by different firms. 
Maxine Brunt, 27, knew something had gone while booking a flight when she didn’t receive a confirmation email.

She (Munich: SOQ.MU - news ) called travel website Expedia (NasdaqGS: EXPE - news ) to check, suggesting she might have mis-typed her email address. She provided other personal details to check against. 
Miss Brunt claims she was told no transaction could be found, so she booked the same flight from Hong Kong to Shanghai again, and paid £118. 
Later, checking her credit card statement, Miss Brunt found she’d paid for two flights. 
She then spent hours on the phone to Expedia and sent several Facebook messages while an agent tried to contact Hong Kong Airlines to authorise a refund. 
Ironically, Miss Brunt chose to use Expedia to book her flight, as she thought if something went wrong, it would be easier to resolve, rather than contacting an airline based in Hong Kong. 
She was told she could only have a part refund of £45. 
Expedia claims it did all it could to find Miss Brunt’s booking, searching for her first and last name, phone number, purchase information as well as potential mis-spellings of her email. 
When they failed to trace the transaction, the customer service agent apparently advised Miss Brunt not to book until she checked her credit card statement. 
Expedia suggests that as Miss Brunt wasn’t signed into her account, her booking wasn’t saved. However, it pointed out its system alerts customers to check their itinerary or email when they come back to the site to book another flight, to avoid a double booking. 
Expedia has now refunded Miss Brunt for the mistakenly booked flight, and given her a £50 flight voucher as a goodwill gesture. 
Ms Brunt said this was inadequate compensation for the "the hours wasted". 
Frank Brehany, consumer director of Holiday TravelWatch, the consumer group, was surprised by Expedia's being unable to find the booking. 
He said if matters like this can’t be resolved amicably, the next step is to try and obtain the telephone transcript to use in your favour. 
Expedia said the best way to avoid such problems is by creating an account where customer details can be saved. If customers don’t sign in and are concerned about a double booking, they should check the transaction on online banking or a bank statement before trying to book again.
